Season 1886

To Shippers
The Lake Steamer will leave Selkirk at 9 o'clock A.M. on Friday, May 28th.

All Goods at Selkirk at this date awaiting shipment by the Saskatchewan River Navigation Company (Limited), through their agent Messrs. Baillie & Co., who will make special rates for shipments and arrange for payments to be made in accordance with the following:

The best packages, accommodation to be sent in Room, Table and Attendance furnished in the steamer.

For further information apply at the Hudson's Bay Company's Office, Prince Albert.

GEO. A. BENTLEY.

SHANNON & McLEOD

CHIT-CHAT LOCALS.

Gathered by our Reporters.

How is Sheep for Rip?
When shall we get our medals?
Choice Cigars at Clark's Drug Store.
What is wheat doing now?

Ladies' Shoulder Bears at Clark's Drug Store.

His Lordship the Bishop will preach in the Roman chapel next Sunday evening.

Aug. 1st

Mr. A. L. Sifton and child (wife) and Mrs. Sifton from Prince Albert came here last evening.

Dominica Brand of Lima Juice is one of the purist and best refined on the market. Sold at Clark's Drug Store.

Mr. H. P. Polson under Superintendent Perry, returned from Regina on Wednesday last.

Mr. F. Pritchard won the cup at the Saskatchewan Rifle Association match yesterday.

Dalmatian Insect Powder. It will kill Cockroaches, it instantly destroys Flies, Bugs and Plaice, Fly. For sale by A. H. Clark.

Photography using young pine canoes, used by the Indians from Spruce Woods, Deer Hill, or by leaving their orders at Tom Turner's.

Miss Stewart of Montreal, arrived here this morning. This young lady is a niece of Mr. John Stewart, merchant, of this town.

An old adage says today will be remembered as a striking and instructive illustration of the comparative worth of the various kinds of baking powders now on the market.

The steamer North West, in charge of Commodore Robert Napier, left for Edmonton, with some 200 tons of freight on board.

A challenge match between two members of the Bridgie Rifles Association, Mr. William E. Baker took place on the range this morning, Mr. Baker firing 77 points and Williamson 55 points. Mr. Baker winning by two points.

Harvest is now in full swing. Mr. R. Macintosh delivered a farewell sermon to his late parishioners at St. Catharine's. There was a large congregation, no doubt many of whom were disappointed not being able to attend the church. The service was impressive, the band played, everybody getting up regularly, and Rev. Mr. Matheson preached at Lindsay, when the audience was so thick that the sermons had to be repeated.

The medal given by the President of the Saskatchewan Rifle Association, and which was won by Mr. T. E. Baker on Monday night, was delivered yesterday afternoon. It is the handsomest design in the way of medals we have seen for years. The medal is an oval mounted with crossed rifles and bayonets and a gold wreath of maple leaves in the center. On the reverse side is the inscription "Given by the President." It has to be won twice by the same competitor.

On Monday evening a large congregational meeting was held at St. Paul's Presbyterian Church, according to the usual custom. Rev. Mr. McWilliam, after making a short address, stated that they had received the Rev. Mr. Matheson's resignation. It was moved by Mr. MacLeod and seconded by Mr. Graham concerning the Presbytery in accepting Mr. McWilliam as a member. Mr. Graham moved that Mr. McWilliam be asked to accept a suitable minister for this charge, who may be expected to arrive here some time in September.

J. D. MAVEETY

PRINCE ALBERT N.W.T.

TERMS—$2.50 per annum in advance.

All letters will be addressed to the Proprietor.

J. D. MAVEETY, Proprietor.

FRIDAY, JULY 30, 1886.

OUR VOLUNTEERS

A few months ago we took occasion to set out in these columns the claims of our volunteers for recognition at the hands of the Government. At that time there was a rather wide spread feeling that our claims were likely to be ignored, but we have always been sanguine enough to expect that full recognition would be forthcoming in time, and the result has proved the correctness of our views.

The last mail brought notices to those who served in the Prince Albert Barracks that the Act 40 Victoria Chapter 90, setting the question at rest in a way that cannot fail to be agreeable to our volunteers.

We may now allow to congratulate all concerned on this decision of the Government, the more so as it is another, and we think a conclusive proof, that the Government are far from entertaining any feeling adverse to the interests of our settlement, and a few热心men seem to dread. Indeed, when along with their action in connection with the Police Barracks, a report is made which will be found in the present issue, it goes to prove that the interests of the important settlement are at present having, and in future will receive ample justice from those in authority.

We have good reason to believe that the Government will be disposed to admit the Prince Albert volunteers to the benefits of the Bounty Act has been at least hastened by the exertions of Capt. Macdonald, who once and again has pled the cause of the local force, and in this he has been ably seconded by Acting-Mayor Betts, his colleague in the late deportations on the barracks matter. New difficulties may arise; but forget that thanks are also due to our member Mr. Hughes, and others who brought the weight of their influence to bear in the right direction.

We have not yet heard whether the volunteers are to receive medals as well as scrip, but we have no doubt this will follow as a natural consequence.

There seems to be little doubt that a new extradition treaty between the United States and Great Britain will be concluded, and that which there will be a reciprocity in defaulters and dynamiters between the two countries. There is no reason why there should be any more difficulty in following a similar practice between Canada and United States or between the United States and Canada, than from one province or state into another. International boundary lines should not afford a screen for crime.

THE SYNOD.

The Synod of the Diocese of Saskatchewan will meet in St. Mary's Church on Wednesday next, the 9th August, at 11 a.m., with the Bishop in the chair. His Lordship the Bishop will preach, as a rule, when at the Synod. Mr. McMillan's in the morning and the Chaplain's in the evening.

FRIDAY, JULY 30, 1886.

COMPARATIVE WORTH OF BAKING POWDERS.

REPORTS OF GOVERNMENT CHEMISTS

As to Purity and Wholesomeness of the Royal Baking Powder.

"The above diagram illustrates the comparative worth of various Baking Powders. The Royal Baking Powder is tested by Professor E. G. Levis, Ph.D., of the University of Pennsylvania, who finds it contains tartar powder of high degree of merit, and does not contain any traces of phosphate, or other injurious substances."

E. G. Levis, Ph.D.

"I have examined a package of Royal Baking Powder purchased by myself in the market. I find it entirely free from alum, torn aside, and placed in a solution of tartar powder of high degree of merit, and does not contain any traces of phosphate, or other injurious substances."

H. A. Mortz, Ph.D.

"I have examined a package of Royal Baking Powder purchased by myself in the market. I find it entirely free from alum, torn aside, and placed in a solution of tartar powder of high degree of merit, and does not contain any traces of phosphate, or other injurious substances."

S. B. Hartz, Ass't Manager, American Institute, New York, and at State Fairs throughout the country.

NOTE.—The above diagram illustrates the comparative worth of various Baking Powders. The Royal Baking Powder is tested by Professor E. G. Levis, Ph.D., of the University of Pennsylvania, who finds it contains tartar powder of high degree of merit, and does not contain any traces of phosphate, or other injurious substances."

THE WEEKLY SUN!

Arrangements are being made by the publishers of THE MANITOBA SUN for the publication of a Weekly Edition at an early date. The price of the paper will be Eight Pages of Seven Columns each—56 Columns in all—and the price will be placed at the very low figure of $1.50 PER ANNUM.

PAYABLE STRICTLY IN ADVANCE.

THE WEEKLY EDITION WILL CONTAIN

The News of the Week, Selected Miscellany, An Interesting Serial, and Special Departments of Peculiar Interest to the Home Circle. No effort will be wanting to make our Weekly a welcome visitor everywhere.

PARTIES intending to subscribe are requested to send their names with the price of subscription to the office of THE MANITOBA SUN, 19 Market St., Winnipeg, Man.
